Web Development.question: What does HTML stand for?
Which CSS property is used to change the text color of an element?
What is the purpose of JavaScript in web development?
choices: To add interactivity to web pages
Web Development.answer: To add interactivity to web pages

Web Development.question: Which HTML tag is used to define an unordered list?
What does CSS stand for?
Which of the following is a JavaScript framework/library?
What HTTP method is typically used to request data from a server?
Which HTML element is used to specify a header for a document or section?
In CSS, what is the 'box model'?
choices: A layout paradigm describing how elements are rendered as rectangular boxes
A way to store CSS variables
Web Development.answer: A layout paradigm describing how elements are rendered as rectangular boxes

Web Development.question: How do you declare a variable in JavaScript?
choices: Both var myVar; and let myVar;
Web Development.answer: Both var myVar; and let myVar;

Web Development.question: What is the correct HTML for referring to an external JavaScript file?
Which CSS property controls the spacing between lines of text?
What does API stand for?
Which HTML tag is used to create a hyperlink?
What is 'Responsive Web Design'?
choices: Designing websites that respond quickly to user input
Designing websites that adapt to different screen sizes and devices
Designing websites that are easy to read
Web Development.answer: Designing websites that adapt to different screen sizes and devices

Web Development.question: How can you include comments in CSS?
Which JavaScript event occurs when the user clicks on an HTML element?
What is the purpose of the HTML `<form>` tag?
choices: To create a container for user input controls
To define a section of navigation links
Web Development.answer: To create a container for user input controls

Web Development.question: In CSS, what does 'flexbox' primarily help with?
choices: Creating complex layouts and aligning items in a container
Web Development.answer: Creating complex layouts and aligning items in a container

Web Development.question: What is JSON?
choices: JavaScript Object Notation - a lightweight data-interchange format
Web Development.answer: JavaScript Object Notation - a lightweight data-interchange format

Web Development.question: Which HTML5 element is used to embed video content?
What is the CSS 'selector'?
choices: A pattern used to select HTML elements to style
A JavaScript function for element selection
A unit of measurement in CSS
Web Development.answer: A pattern used to select HTML elements to style

Web Development.question: What does the `===` operator do in JavaScript?
choices: Compares values for equality without type conversion
Compares values for equality with type conversion
Checks if a value is greater than another
Web Development.answer: Compares values for equality without type conversion

Web Development.question: What is the role of a web server?
choices: To store and deliver web pages to clients upon request
To design the user interface of a website
To execute JavaScript code on the client's machine
Web Development.answer: To store and deliver web pages to clients upon request

Web Development.question: Which CSS unit is relative to the font-size of the element itself?
What is an 'event listener' in JavaScript?
choices: A variable that stores event data
A function that waits for a specific event to occur and then responds to it
A CSS property for event styling
An HTML attribute for defining events
Web Development.answer: A function that waits for a specific event to occur and then responds to it

Web Development.question: Which HTML attribute is used to provide an alternative text for an image, if the image cannot be displayed?
What is CSS Specificity?
choices: A measure of how fast CSS loads
The set of rules browsers use to determine which CSS style applies if multiple styles conflict
A tool for optimizing CSS file sizes
Web Development.answer: The set of rules browsers use to determine which CSS style applies if multiple styles conflict

Web Development.question: What is the DOM in the context of web development?
choices: Document Object Model - a programming interface for HTML and XML documents
Data Object Manager - a database system
Direct Object Manipulation - a JavaScript library
Domain Object Model - a server-side framework
Web Development.answer: Document Object Model - a programming interface for HTML and XML documents

Web Development.question: Which HTTP status code means 'Not Found'?
What is the purpose of the `localStorage` object in web browsers?
choices: To store data that persists only for the current session
To store data with no expiration date on the user's computer
To send data to the server with every request
Web Development.answer: To store data with no expiration date on the user's computer

Web Development.question: Which CSS property is used to create an outline around an element, outside the border?
What is an 'arrow function' in JavaScript?
choices: A function that draws arrows on the screen
A more concise syntax for writing function expressions
A function used for navigating web pages
A function that only works with arrays
Web Development.answer: A more concise syntax for writing function expressions

Web Development.question: Which HTML tag is used to define a table row?
What does 'WCAG' stand for in the context of web accessibility?
How do you select an element with id 'myElement' using CSS?
What is AJAX primarily used for?
choices: To make asynchronous HTTP requests from the client to the server without a full page reload
To define the structure of a web page
Web Development.answer: To make asynchronous HTTP requests from the client to the server without a full page reload

Web Development.question: What is the default display value for a `<div>` element?
Which JavaScript method is used to remove the last element from an array and returns that element?
What is 'Git'?
Which HTML element is used for the largest heading?
What is the purpose of CSS media queries?
choices: To apply different styles for different devices/screen sizes
To play media files like audio and video
Web Development.answer: To apply different styles for different devices/screen sizes

Web Development.question: What does `typeof` operator in JavaScript return for an array?
What is a 'cookie' in web terms?
choices: A small piece of data stored by the browser on the user's computer
Web Development.answer: A small piece of data stored by the browser on the user's computer

Web Development.question: Which CSS property is used to make text bold?
What is the `innerHTML` property in JavaScript used for?
choices: To set the internal styling of an element
To get or set the HTML content within an element
To check if an element is inside another
To define the language of an HTML document
Web Development.answer: To get or set the HTML content within an element

Web Development.question: Which tag is used to embed an image in an HTML page?
What does the 'C' in CRUD stand for in the context of web APIs?
Which of these is a CSS preprocessor?
What is the purpose of the `<!DOCTYPE html>` declaration?
choices: It defines the XML version of the document
It tells the browser that the document is an HTML5 document
It sets the character encoding for the document
Web Development.answer: It tells the browser that the document is an HTML5 document

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is the main function of a CPU?
Computer Fundamentals.answer: Execute program instructions

Computer Fundamentals.question: Which of these is an example of an operating system?
Computer Fundamentals.answer: Windows 10

Computer Fundamentals.question: What does RAM stand for?
Computer Fundamentals.answer: Random Access Memory

Computer Fundamentals.question: Which component is often referred to as the 'brain' of the computer?
Computer Fundamentals.answer: CPU

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is binary code?
choices: A code using letters and numbers
Computer Fundamentals.answer: A code using only 0s and 1s

Computer Fundamentals.question: Which of the following is a type of non-volatile memory?
Computer Fundamentals.answer: SSD (Solid State Drive)

Computer Fundamentals.question: What does 'IP' stand for in TCP/IP?
Computer Fundamentals.answer: Internet Protocol

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is the primary purpose of an IP address?
choices: To identify a device on a network
Computer Fundamentals.answer: To identify a device on a network

Computer Fundamentals.question: Which of these is an input device?
Computer Fundamentals.answer: Keyboard

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is 'software'?
choices: A set of instructions that tells a computer what to do
Computer Fundamentals.answer: A set of instructions that tells a computer what to do

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is a 'byte' typically composed of?
Computer Fundamentals.answer: 8 bits

Computer Fundamentals.question: What does DNS stand for?
Computer Fundamentals.answer: Domain Name System

Computer Fundamentals.question: Which of the following is an example of application software?
Computer Fundamentals.answer: Microsoft Excel

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is a 'file extension'?
choices: The first part of a file name
A set of characters at the end of a file name that indicates the file type
A hidden attribute of a file
Computer Fundamentals.answer: A set of characters at the end of a file name that indicates the file type

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is 'cloud computing'?
choices: Storing data on your local hard drive
Using a network of remote servers hosted on the Internet to store, manage, and process data
A type of weather forecasting software
Connecting computers in a small office
Computer Fundamentals.answer: Using a network of remote servers hosted on the Internet to store, manage, and process data

Computer Fundamentals.question: Which of these is a common type of malware?
Computer Fundamentals.answer: Virus

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is the function of a router in a network?
choices: To provide power to network devices
To forward data packets between computer networks
Computer Fundamentals.answer: To forward data packets between computer networks

Computer Fundamentals.question: What does 'URL' stand for?
Computer Fundamentals.answer: Universal Resource Locator

Computer Fundamentals.question: Which unit is used to measure CPU clock speed?
Computer Fundamentals.answer: Hertz (Hz)

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is an 'algorithm'?
choices: A step-by-step procedure for solving a problem or accomplishing a task
Computer Fundamentals.answer: A step-by-step procedure for solving a problem or accomplishing a task

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is the role of the motherboard in a computer?
choices: To connect all the main components of the computer
Computer Fundamentals.answer: To connect all the main components of the computer

Computer Fundamentals.question: Which of these is an output device?
Computer Fundamentals.answer: Monitor

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is 'phishing'?
choices: A method of catching fish using technology
An attempt to acquire sensitive information by masquerading as a trustworthy entity
A software for cleaning computer viruses
Computer Fundamentals.answer: An attempt to acquire sensitive information by masquerading as a trustworthy entity

Computer Fundamentals.question: What does 'GUI' stand for?
Computer Fundamentals.answer: Graphical User Interface

Computer Fundamentals.question: Which type of software is designed to protect your computer from malware?
Computer Fundamentals.answer: Antivirus Software

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is a 'server' in the context of computer networks?
choices: A computer that provides services or resources to other computers (clients)
The main computer used by an individual
A software for browsing the web
Computer Fundamentals.answer: A computer that provides services or resources to other computers (clients)

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is the term for the physical parts of a computer system?
Computer Fundamentals.answer: Hardware

Computer Fundamentals.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of RAM?
choices: Volatile (loses data when power is off)
Used for booting the OS only
Computer Fundamentals.answer: Volatile (loses data when power is off)

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is the purpose of a 'firewall'?
choices: To prevent unauthorized access to or from a private network
Computer Fundamentals.answer: To prevent unauthorized access to or from a private network

Computer Fundamentals.question: What does 'HTTP' stand for?
Computer Fundamentals.answer: HyperText Transfer Protocol

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is a 'pixel'?
choices: The smallest addressable element in a raster image
Computer Fundamentals.answer: The smallest addressable element in a raster image

Computer Fundamentals.question: Which part of the computer is responsible for storing the operating system and user files when the computer is off?
Computer Fundamentals.answer: Hard Drive / SSD

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is 'open-source software'?
choices: Software whose source code is available for modification or enhancement by anyone
Software that can only be used online
Software that has not been released yet
Computer Fundamentals.answer: Software whose source code is available for modification or enhancement by anyone

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is the function of an 'Ethernet cable'?
choices: To connect a monitor to a computer
To provide power to a computer
To connect devices in a local area network (LAN)
Computer Fundamentals.answer: To connect devices in a local area network (LAN)

Computer Fundamentals.question: What does 'Wi-Fi' use to transmit data?
Computer Fundamentals.answer: Radio waves

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is a 'kernel' in an operating system?
choices: The core component that manages system resources
Computer Fundamentals.answer: The core component that manages system resources

Computer Fundamentals.question: Which number system has a base of 16?
Computer Fundamentals.answer: Hexadecimal

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is 'multitasking' in an operating system?
choices: The ability to execute multiple tasks or processes concurrently
Computer Fundamentals.answer: The ability to execute multiple tasks or processes concurrently

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is a 'backup' in computing?
choices: A copy of data that can be used to restore the original in case of data loss
A security feature to prevent viruses
A way to speed up the computer
Computer Fundamentals.answer: A copy of data that can be used to restore the original in case of data loss

Computer Fundamentals.question: What does 'SaaS' stand for in cloud computing?
Computer Fundamentals.answer: Software as a Service

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is a 'Trojan horse' in cybersecurity?
choices: A type of malware disguised as legitimate software
Computer Fundamentals.answer: A type of malware disguised as legitimate software

Computer Fundamentals.question: Which of these is a peripheral device?
Computer Fundamentals.answer: Printer

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is the primary role of a 'compiler'?
choices: To execute code line by line
To translate source code from a high-level programming language to a lower-level language (e.g., machine code)
Computer Fundamentals.answer: To translate source code from a high-level programming language to a lower-level language (e.g., machine code)

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is 'virtual memory'?
choices: A memory management capability of an OS that uses hardware and software to allow a computer to compensate for physical memory shortages
A type of very fast RAM
Memory used by virtual reality headsets
Computer Fundamentals.answer: A memory management capability of an OS that uses hardware and software to allow a computer to compensate for physical memory shortages

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is a 'cookie' in the context of web browsing (related to computer fundamentals)?
choices: A small piece of data sent from a website and stored on the user's computer by the web browser
A hardware component for storing data
A snack eaten while using the computer
Computer Fundamentals.answer: A small piece of data sent from a website and stored on the user's computer by the web browser

Computer Fundamentals.question: What does 'LAN' stand for?
Computer Fundamentals.answer: Local Area Network

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is 'firmware'?
choices: A type of very soft hardware
Permanent software programmed into a read-only memory.
Software that is not yet complete
Computer Fundamentals.answer: Permanent software programmed into a read-only memory.

Computer Fundamentals.question: Which of these best describes a 'database'?
choices: An organized collection of structured information, or data, typically stored electronically in a computer system
Computer Fundamentals.answer: An organized collection of structured information, or data, typically stored electronically in a computer system

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is 'encryption'?
choices: The process of converting information or data into a code, especially to prevent unauthorized access
Computer Fundamentals.answer: The process of converting information or data into a code, especially to prevent unauthorized access

Computer Fundamentals.question: What is the 'Internet of Things (IoT)'?
choices: A new version of the internet
A network of physical objects embedded with sensors, software, and other technologies for connecting and exchanging data with other devices and systems over the internet
A specific brand of smart home devices
Computer Fundamentals.answer: A network of physical objects embedded with sensors, software, and other technologies for connecting and exchanging data with other devices and systems over the internet

Programming Concepts.question: What is a variable in programming?
choices: A named storage location for data
Programming Concepts.answer: A named storage location for data

Programming Concepts.question: Which keyword is commonly used to define a function in Python?
Programming Concepts.answer: def

Programming Concepts.question: What is an 'if-else' statement used for?
Programming Concepts.answer: Making decisions based on conditions

Programming Concepts.question: What is a 'loop' in programming?
choices: A way to stop program execution
A structure that repeats a block of code multiple times
Programming Concepts.answer: A structure that repeats a block of code multiple times

Programming Concepts.question: Which of these is a common data type?
Programming Concepts.answer: Integer

Programming Concepts.question: What does 'OOP' stand for?
Programming Concepts.answer: Object-Oriented Programming

Programming Concepts.question: What is an 'array' (or list in some languages)?
Programming Concepts.answer: An ordered collection of items

Programming Concepts.question: What is 'debugging'?
choices: The process of finding and fixing errors in code
Programming Concepts.answer: The process of finding and fixing errors in code

Programming Concepts.question: What is a 'function' or 'method' in programming?
choices: A variable that holds multiple values
A block of code designed to perform a specific task
Programming Concepts.answer: A block of code designed to perform a specific task

Programming Concepts.question: What is 'syntax' in programming?
choices: The logical flow of a program
The set of rules that defines how a program must be written
Programming Concepts.answer: The set of rules that defines how a program must be written

Programming Concepts.question: Which of the following is a 'Boolean' value?
Programming Concepts.answer: true

Programming Concepts.question: What is a 'class' in Object-Oriented Programming?
Programming Concepts.answer: A blueprint for creating objects

Programming Concepts.question: What does 'API' stand for in a programming context?
Programming Concepts.answer: Application Programming Interface

Programming Concepts.question: What is 'pseudocode'?
choices: Code written in a specific programming language
An informal, high-level description of the operating principle of a computer program or algorithm
Programming Concepts.answer: An informal, high-level description of the operating principle of a computer program or algorithm

Programming Concepts.question: What is 'recursion'?
Programming Concepts.answer: A function calling itself

Programming Concepts.question: What is 'source code'?
choices: The compiled version of a program
The human-readable instructions written by a programmer
Programming Concepts.answer: The human-readable instructions written by a programmer

Programming Concepts.question: What is a 'compiler'?
choices: A program that executes code line by line
A program that translates source code into machine code or another lower-level language
A text editor for writing code
Programming Concepts.answer: A program that translates source code into machine code or another lower-level language

Programming Concepts.question: What is an 'interpreter'?
choices: A program that translates entire source code into machine code at once
A program that directly executes instructions written in a programming language line by line
Programming Concepts.answer: A program that directly executes instructions written in a programming language line by line

Programming Concepts.question: What is 'inheritance' in OOP?
choices: A mechanism where a new class derives properties and methods from an existing class
A way to create multiple instances of a class
A method for hiding internal class details
Programming Concepts.answer: A mechanism where a new class derives properties and methods from an existing class

Programming Concepts.question: What is 'encapsulation' in OOP?
choices: Bundling data (attributes) and methods that operate on the data into a single unit (class), and restricting access to some of the object's components
Programming Concepts.answer: Bundling data (attributes) and methods that operate on the data into a single unit (class), and restricting access to some of the object's components

Programming Concepts.question: What is a 'string' data type?
Programming Concepts.answer: A sequence of characters

Programming Concepts.question: What is a 'parameter' or 'argument' of a function?
choices: The value returned by the function
A value passed into a function when it is called
A variable defined inside a function
Programming Concepts.answer: A value passed into a function when it is called

Programming Concepts.question: What does 'IDE' stand for?
Programming Concepts.answer: Integrated Development Environment

Programming Concepts.question: What is 'version control' (e.g., Git)?
choices: A system for managing different versions of software
A tool for checking code syntax
A system for tracking and managing changes to code over time
Programming Concepts.answer: A system for tracking and managing changes to code over time

Programming Concepts.question: What is an 'object' in OOP?
Programming Concepts.answer: An instance of a class

Programming Concepts.question: What is a 'comment' in programming code?
choices: A piece of text ignored by the compiler/interpreter, used for explanations
Programming Concepts.answer: A piece of text ignored by the compiler/interpreter, used for explanations

Programming Concepts.question: What is 'polymorphism' in OOP?
choices: The ability of an object to take on many forms, or for a method to behave differently based on the object that calls it
Creating multiple copies of an object
A function that calls itself many times
Programming Concepts.answer: The ability of an object to take on many forms, or for a method to behave differently based on the object that calls it

Programming Concepts.question: Which operator is commonly used for assignment in many programming languages?
What is a 'data structure'?
choices: A way to structure comments in code
A particular way of organizing and storing data in a computer so that it can be accessed and modified efficiently
A type of control flow statement
A hardware component for data storage
Programming Concepts.answer: A particular way of organizing and storing data in a computer so that it can be accessed and modified efficiently

Programming Concepts.question: What is 'error handling'?
choices: The process of anticipating, detecting, and resolving errors in software
Writing code that never has errors
Programming Concepts.answer: The process of anticipating, detecting, and resolving errors in software

Programming Concepts.question: What is a 'for loop' typically used for?
choices: Executing a block of code if a condition is true
Iterating over a sequence (like an array or list) or executing a block of code a specific number of times
Programming Concepts.answer: Iterating over a sequence (like an array or list) or executing a block of code a specific number of times

Programming Concepts.question: What is 'scope' in programming?
choices: The length of a variable name
The context in which a variable is defined and can be accessed
The number of lines in a program
Programming Concepts.answer: The context in which a variable is defined and can be accessed

Programming Concepts.question: Which data structure uses a LIFO (Last-In, First-Out) principle?
Programming Concepts.answer: Stack

Programming Concepts.question: Which data structure uses a FIFO (First-In, First-Out) principle?
Programming Concepts.answer: Queue

Programming Concepts.question: What is 'abstraction' in programming?
choices: Hiding complex implementation details and showing only the essential features of an object or system
Writing code that is very specific
Programming Concepts.answer: Hiding complex implementation details and showing only the essential features of an object or system

Programming Concepts.question: What is a 'library' in programming?
choices: A place to store old code
A collection of pre-written code, functions, and routines that can be used by programmers to perform common tasks
Programming Concepts.answer: A collection of pre-written code, functions, and routines that can be used by programmers to perform common tasks

Programming Concepts.question: What is 'null' or 'nil' often used to represent in programming?
choices: The absence of a value or a non-existent object
Programming Concepts.answer: The absence of a value or a non-existent object

Programming Concepts.question: What is a 'constant'?
choices: A value that cannot be altered by the program during normal execution
Programming Concepts.answer: A value that cannot be altered by the program during normal execution

Programming Concepts.question: What is 'iteration'?
choices: The process of repeating a set of instructions
Programming Concepts.answer: The process of repeating a set of instructions

Programming Concepts.question: What is 'type casting' or 'type conversion'?
choices: Changing the name of a variable
Converting a value from one data type to another
Programming Concepts.answer: Converting a value from one data type to another

Programming Concepts.question: What is a 'keyword' or 'reserved word' in a programming language?
choices: A word that programmers can freely use for variable names
A word that has a special meaning to the compiler/interpreter and cannot be used as an identifier (e.g., variable name)
Programming Concepts.answer: A word that has a special meaning to the compiler/interpreter and cannot be used as an identifier (e.g., variable name)

Programming Concepts.question: What is the primary purpose of a 'constructor' in OOP?
choices: To initialize a new object of a class
Programming Concepts.answer: To initialize a new object of a class

Programming Concepts.question: What is 'Big O Notation' used for?
choices: Describing the size of a program
Describing the performance or complexity of an algorithm (e.g., its execution time or space requirements)
Programming Concepts.answer: Describing the performance or complexity of an algorithm (e.g., its execution time or space requirements)

Programming Concepts.question: What is a 'pointer' (in languages like C/C++)?
choices: A variable that stores a boolean value
A variable that stores the memory address of another variable
A graphical element on the screen
Programming Concepts.answer: A variable that stores the memory address of another variable

Programming Concepts.question: What is a 'framework' in software development?
choices: A pre-written set of code and tools that provides a structure for developing software applications
Programming Concepts.answer: A pre-written set of code and tools that provides a structure for developing software applications

Programming Concepts.question: What does it mean for a programming language to be 'statically typed'?
choices: Variables can change type during execution
Variable types are checked at compile-time, and usually cannot change
Programming Concepts.answer: Variable types are checked at compile-time, and usually cannot change

Programming Concepts.question: What does it mean for a programming language to be 'dynamically typed'?
choices: Variable types are checked only at compile-time
Variable types are checked at run-time, and can often change
Programming Concepts.answer: Variable types are checked at run-time, and can often change

Programming Concepts.question: What is a 'hash table' or 'dictionary' or 'map' data structure?
choices: A data structure that stores key-value pairs
Programming Concepts.answer: A data structure that stores key-value pairs

Programming Concepts.question: What is 'refactoring' code?
choices: Restructuring existing computer code changing the factoring without changing its external behavior
Programming Concepts.answer: Restructuring existing computer code changing the factoring without changing its external behavior

Programming Concepts.question: What is an 'exception' in programming?
choices: A normal part of program flow
An event, which occurs during the execution of a program, that disrupts the normal flow of the program's instructions
Programming Concepts.answer: An event, which occurs during the execution of a program, that disrupts the normal flow of the program's instructions
